speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: What blood type are you, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: Ah, you mean the different groups used to classify humans by blood – types A, B, AB and O. I think I’m type O. How about you, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, it may sound strange but actually I don’t know.

speaker: Sam
text: Hmm, lots of westerners don’t know their blood type, but in parts of Asia blood groups are a topic of daily conversation. People select romantic partners based on blood type and different blood groups are associated with different personalities.

speaker: Neil
text: In this programme we’ll be finding out all about blood – why humans have different blood types and whether blood is something more than just a way of pumping oxygen around your body.

speaker: Sam
text: And of course we’ll be learning some new vocabulary as well. Now, Neil, I have an interesting fact for you - did you know that many Japanese popstars’ websites will feature their blood type alongside information like their age and hobbies?

speaker: Neil
text: I didn’t, Sam, but Japanese culture is certainly interested in blood. There’s even a word ‘burahara’ meaning ‘blood harassment’, which is used to describe hostility towards people from a certain blood group considered to be selfish – but which group? That’s my quiz question for today – which blood types may fall victim to ‘burahara’? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) blood type A?

speaker: Neil
text: b) blood type B?   Or

speaker: Neil
text: c) blood type O?

speaker: Sam
text: I’ll say a) blood type A.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out the answer later. As we’ve heard, blood is a big deal in Japan. Marnie Chesterton, from BBC World Service programme, CrowdScience, travelled to Tokyo where she asked Japanese translator, Chie Kobayashi, to explain more:

speaker: perfectionists
text: For blood type A, generally it is thought they are perfectionists, more detail-oriented, pretty much good at precise type jobs, and that makes them good at helping others and good at teamwork and respecting rules and customs. That’s a typical blood A type.

speaker: stubborn,woe betide
text: 40 percent of Japan’s population are sensitive, anxious type As. 30 percent are curious and stubborn, generous type Os. Ten percent are creative ABs. But woe betide the twenty percent type Bs because they have a far less desirable personality, apparently.

speaker: perfectionists
text: According to Japanese tradition, blood type As are perfectionists - people who want everything to be perfect and demand the highest standards possible.

speaker: stubborn
text: This contrasts with type Os who are considered to be stubborn – people who are determined to do what they want and refuse to change their mind.

speaker: Woe betide
text: But it’s unfortunate blood type Bs who have the least desirable personality – selfish and independent. “Woe betide the type Bs” remarks the presenter, Marnie Chesterton – an informal British expression said when there will be trouble ahead for someone – in this case, poor type Bs!

speaker: Neil
text: But apart from customs and traditions, is there actually any science behind these beliefs?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, not according to Dr Emma Pomeroy of Cambridge University’s archaeology department. She thinks that - like horoscopes – there’s no scientific basis for a connection between blood types and personalities.

speaker: Neil
text: Which makes me wonder what exactly blood types are.

speaker: immune system
text: Blood types are kinds of stickers or chemical markers which support our immune system - the organs, cells and processes which protect the human body from infection and illness.

speaker: pathogens -
text: Those chemical markers can identify foreign bodies like pathogens - small organisms, such a virus or bacteria, that can cause disease. The variety of blood types seems to be a result of different bodily responses to different disease-causing pathogens.

speaker: blood transfusions
text: Which explains why blood of the same type is needed in blood transfusions – medical procedures in which blood is taken from one person and put into another person’s body, often after an accident or during an operation.

speaker: Neil
text: And explains the high demand for type O blood which can be given to anyone.

speaker: Sam
text: Ah, generous type Os – like me. I always knew I was special… and curious and stubborn, wasn’t that the type O personality?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes, today’s quiz question was about blood type personalities. I asked you which undesirable blood type is considered selfish in Japan.

speaker: Sam
text: I said a) blood type A.

speaker: Neil
text: But as we’ve heard, it’s actually b) blood type B.

speaker: perfectionists -
text: Never mind, I’ll settle for being curious, stubborn and generous! In today’s programme we’ve been talking all about blood types and personalities. In Japan, blood type A people are thought of as perfectionists - people who want everything to be perfect.

speaker: stubborn
text: Unlike type Os who are considered stubborn – determined to get their own way and unwilling to change.

speaker: woe betide
text: And woe betide selfish type Bs – an informal expression said when there will be trouble for someone or if they will be punished for doing a particular thing.

speaker: immune system
text: Scientifically speaking, blood types help support our immune system - the organs and cellular processes which protect the human body from infection.

speaker: pathogens -
text: They also help identify foreign pathogens - small organisms, such a virus or bacteria, that can cause a disease.

speaker: blood transfusion
text: And explain why the same blood type is needed for a successful blood transfusion – the procedure in which blood is transferred from one person’s body to another during an operation.

speaker: Sam
text: That’s all we have time for today. Bye for now.

speaker: Neil
text: Bye!
